Award.AwardTitle: New Variational Methods for Quasi-static and Dynamic Material Defect Evolution
Award.AbstractNarration:
Larsen
1313136

While defects in materials play a fundamental role in material failure, their analysis remains a major challenge in applied mathematics. This is partly due to the difficulty of formulating precise mathematical models, and partly due to the difficulty of analyzing the free surfaces and singularities involved. The investigator extends recent successes in the analysis of globally minimizing and locally minimizing quasi-static evolutions to both locally stable quasi-static evolutions and dynamic evolutions. One goal is to develop and study new models for cohesive fracture and plasticity with softening, based on local stability rather than global minimality (which is mathematically problematic). The investigator also studies existence and analyzes fundamental properties of dynamic fracture solutions, based on models he formulated previously.

The failure of materials rests on the nucleation and evolution of defects such as cracks, plastic regions, and damage. The ability to accurately predict failure depends on the quality of the underlying mathematical models of these defects, as well as on understanding fundamental properties of solutions. Substantial challenges remain in these areas, both in formulating sound models and in the analysis of qualitative behavior of solutions. The investigator seeks to make fundamental progress on these fronts, by developing new models that are both mathematically well-posed and significantly more physically realistic than existing models, and performing the mathematical analysis necessary to assess their accuracy.

POR.DRECONTENT:
The main goal of this project was to substantially further the development of models and analysis for the evolution of defects in materials (such as fracture and plasticity), including developing a new stability criterion and initiating progress on dynamic fracture. The project funded a Ph.D. student, and also involved collaborations with several undergraduates. 

The primary mathematical results include establishing existence for dynamic fracture with a maximal dissipation condition (the first result of its kind), developed a new stability criterion for plasticity (which included work with an undergraduate), extended a threshold condition for damage to elasticity, partial results for cohesive fracture, including dynamics.

There are two main areas of broader impact: outreach and training, and strengthening connections between rigorous analysis and engineering applications. Introducing students to problems in mathematical analysis, within a clear context of important applications, is something I have consistently enjoyed doing, and I believe is critical to developing the next generation of applied mathematicians. For this project, I was particularly fortunate to involve four strong undergraduates. All have continued to graduate school: Carnegie Mellon, Cambridge, University of Texas-Austin, and University of California-Berkeley. 

I have also had a role in training students outside of my institution. In the summer of 2014, the Institute for Advanced Study/Park City Mathematics Institute (PCMI) ran a program on Mathematics and Materials, and they asked me to teach an advanced undergraduate course, which I was happy to do. I gave a course on "Variational methods for materials science," with the goal of giving a sense of the interesting mathematical issues that arise at the research level. This PCMI program has a particularly strong outreach component, and there were a number of students from underrepresented groups.

In addition, I have played a visible role in connecting rigorous analysis with engineering applications, which has been recognized in the engineering community: I was invited to give an hour invited talk at an IUTAM meeting, a keynote lecture at a CFRAC conference, and I was invited to an interdisciplinary meeting on fracture at the Lorentz Center this spring. I also co-organized a highly interdisciplinary workshop on fracture at Banff this May (a meeting with many people outside of mathematics, and a very small number of analysts).
